content_parts.text: —Zechariah, whose name means “he whom God remembers.” He was born in Babylon, returning to Judah in 537 BC.
Zechariah's prophetic ministry was well established in Babylon among the people in captivity.
He was from the tribe of Judah, succeeding his grandfather Addo as a prophet.
Haggai was his contemporary.
Zechariah is commemorated on February 8.
Zechariah's prophecies coincide with those of Haggai.
Encouraging the returned captives to rebuild the temple
Encouraging the returned captives to rebuild the temple
The prophecies of Zechariah are messianic, apocalyptic, and eschatological.
Zechariah foretold Christ's coming in lowliness and humility (
), His rejection and betrayal for thirty pieces of silver (
), His crucifixion (
), His priesthood (
), His heritage (
), His coming in glory (
), His building of the Lord's temple (
), his reign (
), and His establishment of peace and prosperity (

metadata.title: As to the apocalyptic and eschatological emphasis, the prophecies foretold the invasion of Jerusalem (12:1–3; 14:1, 2), the victory of Judah's enemies (14:2), the Lord's defense of Jerusalem (14:3, 4), the judgment on the nations (12:9; 14:3), the geographical changes in Judah (14:4, 5), the commemoration of the Feast of Tabernacles in the messianic age (14:16–19), and the fulfillment of the prophecies about the holiness of the Israelites (14:20, 21).

metadata.title: This book also develops the theology of angels, as God communicates through them to Zechariah. Many New Testament apocalyptic images are foreshadowed in this book.

Many New Testament apocalyptic images are foreshadowed in this book.
—In the first year of Cyrus the Great of Persia, a decree was issued permitting the return of the Jews to Jerusalem with a commission to rebuild the temple.
The Israelites were led back by Zerubbabel and Joshua.
Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, was the heir to the throne of David.
In 520 BC, Zechariah and Haggai attempted to rouse the remnant of returned exiles to rebuild the temple.
